question: How many tornadoes will NOAA report for March 2025?
news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**Canada saw longest tornado season on record in 2024, with Ontario hit hardest**
Canada experienced its longest tornado season on record in 2024, spanning nine months from March 16 to November 10. Ontario was the hardest hit province, with 50 tornadoes recorded over land and 10 over water. According to David Sills, executive director of the Northern Tornadoes Project at Western University, 'It's the longest tornado season on record since at least 1980, according to our records.' The 129 tornadoes nationwide last year is the second-highest number ever documented by the team, with the record being 131 set in 2022.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 06, 2025 11:07 PM
Source:[The Star](https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/canada-saw-longest-tornado-season-on-record-in-2024-with-ontario-hit-hardest/article_6c12f412-e4d1-11ef-bb65-7f70b6f899d6.html)

**Over 1.4 million receive tornado alerts in Kentucky**
Over 1.4 million Kentucky residents have received tornado alerts for an imminent storm set to hit the state on Thursday. The National Weather Service (NWS) has placed 22 counties under watch, which are home to more than a dozen schools in the possible vortex path. NOAA has issued a Tornado Watch 3, warning of severe storms capable of producing brief tornadoes, strong gusts, and isolated small hail. Emergency officials have issued a shelter in place for residents in the Enslow Park community, advising them to prepare to seek high ground if possible. The NWS expects thunderstorms to continue overnight, threatening the region with more damaging winds, hail, and tornadoes. 'A Tornado Watch means conditions are favorable for tornadoes and severe thunderstorms in and close to the watch area,' NOAA shared. 'Persons in these areas should be on the lookout for threatening weather conditions and listen for later statements and possible warnings.' 
Original language: en
Publish date: February 06, 2025 05:46 PM
Source:[Daily Mail Online](https://www.dailymail.co.uk/galleries/article-14368995/Over-1-4-million-receive-tornado-alerts-Kentucky.html)

**Numerous schools in danger due to approaching tornado, prompting ‘life-threatening’ warnings for millions**
More than 1.4 million Kentucky residents received alerts about an imminent tornado set to hit part of the state on Thursday. The National Weather Service (NWS) placed 22 counties under watch until 11am ET, which are home to more than a dozen schools in the possible vortex path. The NWS stated that 'some locations that will experience flash flooding include Whitesburg, Hyden, Letcher, Jenkins, Elkhorn City, Fleming-Neon, Vicco, Blackey, Cornettsville, Ulvah, Daisy, Bluefield, Arminta, Red Star, Sassafras, Hallie, Viper, Gander, Jeff and Slemp.' Residents are warned to turn around on roads that appear flooded to avoid drowning, as 'most flood deaths occur in vehicles.' Emergency officials issued a shelter in place for residents in the Enslow Park community early Thursday. The NWS stated that thunderstorms are expected to continue overnight, threatening the region with more damaging winds, hail and tornadoes. 'A Tornado Watch means conditions are favorable for tornadoes and severe thunderstorms in and close to the watch area,' NOAA shared. The last tornado to rip through Kentucky hit in April 2024, sparking a state of emergency following the severe storms and tornadoes that came.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 06, 2025 04:28 PM
Source:[internewscast.com](https://internewscast.com/news/us/numerous-schools-in-danger-due-to-approaching-tornado-prompting-life-threatening-warnings-for-millions/)

**Imminent tornado sparks 'danger to life' alerts for millions**
More than 1.4 million Kentucky residents have received alerts about an imminent tornado set to hit part of the state Thursday. The National Weather Service (NWS) has placed 22 counties under watch until 11am ET, which are home to more than a dozen schools in the possible vortex path. NOAA has issued an 'immediate broadcast' of a Tornado Watch 3, warning residents about numerous severe storms. 'A line of thunderstorms is currently moving across central Kentucky,' NOAA's alert reads. 'This line has intensified over the past hour and environmental conditions are expected to remain supportive of strong to severe thunderstorms capable of producing brief tornadoes, strong gusts, and isolated small hail.' The NWS stated thunderstorms are expected to continue overnight, threatening the region with more damaging winds, hail and tornadoes. Residents in the counties under watch share pictures of the incoming storm, revealing a dark, ominous sky in the early morning. 'A Tornado Watch means conditions are favorable for tornadoes and severe thunderstorms in and close to the watch area,' NOAA shared. Winds in the area are expected to hit 70mph. Residents have already seen damage to their properties. 'Persons in these areas should be on the lookout for threatening weather conditions and listen for later statements and possible warnings,' NOAA advised. The last tornado to rip through Kentucky hit in April 2024, sparking a state of emergency following the severe storms and tornadoes that came.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 06, 2025 04:04 PM
Source:[Daily Mail Online](https://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-14368547/Multiple-school-risk-imminent-tornado-sparks-danger-life-alerts-millions.html)

**West Alabama EMA director urges planning now for tornado season**
Hale County EMA director Russ Weeden is urging residents to prepare for tornado season, which can occur in any month in Alabama, but tends to be more severe in the spring. Weeden, who has seen his share of bad weather, including 6 tornadoes in a 12-month period, emphasizes the importance of having a plan in place. 'Always have a plan. What are you going to do when that tornado alarm goes off, where are you going to go, make sure your neighbors know about it. Now is the time for planning,' Weeden said. The county will be conducting a major tornado drill on March 13, involving over 600 first responders and 40 volunteers, to sharpen communication skills and prepare for the worst-case scenario. Weeden notes that the worst possible scenario would be a tornado hitting Main Street, wiping out communications, the hospital, and schools.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 06, 2025 12:50 AM
Source:[wbrc.com](https://www.wbrc.com/2025/02/06/west-alabama-ema-director-urges-planning-now-tornado-season/)

**Severe Weather Awareness Week Day 3: what you need to know about tornadoes**
Day 3 of Severe Weather Awareness Week focuses on tornado and thunderstorm safety. According to the National Weather Service, an average of 800 tornadoes are reported nationwide every year, with the peak season for Florida and surrounding southern states being March through May. Bay County officials emphasize the importance of staying connected and making a plan to stay prepared. 'Being able to receive alerts is the primary of importance. And then the second thing is making sure you have a plan and you know what you’re going to do to react to the issuance of a tornado watch or a tornado warning,' said Bay County manager Bob Majka. A tornado watch is when people should be ready and prepared, while a tornado warning is when they should take action and seek shelter. In 2024, Florida saw over 100 tornadoes, with 6 hitting the Panhandle in January. Officials stress that having a disaster plan is crucial, which includes knowing the best place to seek shelter and checking home insurance coverage. 'We always encourage people, make sure you understand what your insurance policy covers, understand, you know, what those benefits are,' said Majka.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 06, 2025 12:35 AM
Source:[mypanhandle.com](https://www.mypanhandle.com/news/local-news/bay-county/severe-weather-awareness-week-day-3-what-you-need-to-know-about-tornadoes/)

**30 Tornadoes in a Year: Unusual Activity in 2024**
According to the French tornado and violent storm observatory, Keraunos, the year 2024 saw a 'higher than normal' tornado activity, with 30 tornadoes recorded in a year, spread over 22 days. This is similar to the activity seen in 2023, but not as high as the record of 50 tornadoes in 2014. Keraunos notes that the year 2024 was marked by a significant tornado, an EF2, which occurred in Carlepont, Oise on June 18, 2024. The tornado activity was unusual, with 'usual' tornadoes in the northwest and more surprising ones in the southwest and center-east. 'The year 2024 has presented an above-normal tornado activity, marked by frequent tornadoes in the spring and autumn', said Keraunos.
Original language: fr
Publish date: February 05, 2025 03:20 PM
Source:[Futura](https://www.futura-sciences.com/planete/breves/meteorologie-30-tornades-an-taux-superieur-normale-voici-regions-plus-frappees-france-10410/)

**Being a Louisiana weather forecaster isn't easy. But 2025 snowstorm offered a rare bit of joy.**
Mike Efferson, a meteorologist at the National Weather Service office in Slidell, Louisiana, has had to deal with many severe weather events in his 17-year career. However, the 2025 snowstorm that brought historic amounts of snow and record cold temperatures to south Louisiana was a rare and magical experience for him and his family. Efferson's daughters, 7-year-old Mariana and 4-year-old Melise, had never seen snow before, and the family enjoyed a fun-filled day playing in the snow, making snow angels, and having a snowball fight. Efferson, who has worked through many devastating weather events, including hurricanes and tornado outbreaks, said that this event was a welcome change from the usual high-pressure situations he faces. 'It was really exciting and it was really hard to believe,' Efferson said. 'All the pictures and videos were of people smiling and having fun.' 
Original language: en
Publish date: February 05, 2025 12:06 PM
Source:[NOLA](https://www.nola.com/news/weather/forecaster-louisiana-snowstorm/article_71d60d88-de70-11ef-9282-8f23fd281362.html)

**James McAvoy to appear at Glasgow Film Festival in star studded line up**
The 2025 Glasgow Film Festival (GFF) has announced a star-studded lineup, featuring Hollywood actors James McAvoy, Jessica Lange, and Ed Harris, among others. The festival will host 13 world and European premieres, 66 UK premieres, and 12 Scottish premieres from 38 countries. Notable attendees include Tim Roth, Koki, Takehiro Hira, and John Maclean, who will attend the world premiere of their survival thriller Tornado. Lange will also appear in a special In Conversation event, reflecting on her six-decade-long screen career. Other notable events include the world premiere of the documentary Hill, featuring Formula One champion Damon Hill, and the Scottish premiere of the post-apocalyptic musical The End, starring George MacKay. The festival runs from February 26 to March 9 at the Glasgow Film Theatre and venues across the city.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 05, 2025 04:35 AM
Source:[Daily Record](https://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/scottish-news/hollywood-movie-stars-set-light-34616016)

**Monsterwetter: Erdrutsch, Fluten und Tornados**
The documentary series 'Monsterwetter: Erdrutsch, Fluten und Tornados' will premiere on National Geographic on March 5, 2025. The series explores extreme weather events that are becoming more frequent and unpredictable, causing devastating consequences. The show highlights the rapid development of these events into existential threats, featuring dramatic footage of storms, wildfires, and tornadoes. Experts, including climate researchers, will share their insights, and survivors will share their personal stories. The series aims to raise awareness about the challenges posed by climate change and the increasing average global temperature.
Original language: de
Publish date: January 12, 2025 12:52 PM
Source:[quotenmeter.de](https://www.quotenmeter.de/n/157915/monsterwetter-erdrutsch-fluten-und-tornados-tv-premiere-ueber-naturkatastrophen)

**2025 First Major Storm Forecasted to Impact 60 Million Americans**
A major storm is forecasted to impact approximately 60 million Americans, bringing torrential downpours, fierce winds, and possible tornadoes. Experts warn residents to take necessary precautions, including securing loose objects, stocking up on emergency supplies, and heeding evacuation orders if issued. Emergency response teams are on high alert, and local authorities are coordinating evacuation plans and setting up shelters. The community's cooperation is crucial in ensuring a swift and effective response to the impending crisis. As the storm draws near, it is essential to stay informed through official channels and follow guidelines and recommendations from authorities. By working together and supporting one another, we can weather this storm and emerge stronger on the other side.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 05, 2025 01:33 PM
Source:[usanews.net](https://usanews.net/breaking/2025-first-major-storm-forecasted-to-impact-60-million-americans.html)

**Expensive and deadly: Near record number of tornadoes reported in 2024**
The year 2024 ended with a record number of tornadoes, with at least 1,855 preliminary reports, including 90 in December. The National Weather Service expects the final total to be over 1,700 tornadoes, making it the second worst year on record, except for 2004. The year was marked by a lack of significant lull in activity, with smaller active days aggregating to a high total. At least 50 people died, and Oklahoma had its worst year on record with 152 confirmed twisters. Several other states also broke their previous records for tornadoes. Researchers attribute the increase in tornado activity to a particularly active jet stream, the transition from El Niño to neutral conditions, and an exceptionally warm Gulf of Mexico. 'We just never really got a break,' said Victor Gensini, an associate professor of meteorology and severe weather at Northern Illinois University. 'This (2024) will be the highest year for insured losses for severe convective storms - including hail, wind and tornadoes - by a large margin,' Gensini said.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 05, 2025 10:11 AM
Source:[Yahoo](https://www.yahoo.com/news/expensive-deadly-near-record-number-100806072.html)

**California wildfire alert camera captures video of country’s first tornado of 2025**
A wildfire alert camera in Northern California captured video of what is believed to be the country's first tornado of 2025. The tornado was detected by meteorologists at the National Weather Service office in Sacramento, who issued a Tornado Warning for the affected area. According to statistics from NOAA's Storm Prediction Center, California typically experiences fewer than a dozen tornadoes each year, and they are generally on the weaker end of the Enhanced Fujita Wind Scale. The storm system that produced the tornado could lead to additional rotating supercells late in the weekend and early next week along the Gulf Coast. The total number of tornadoes in 2024 was 1,735, more than 40% higher than the typical number of tornadoes seen in an average year across the U.S.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 04, 2025 04:35 AM
Source:[foxweather.com](https://www.foxweather.com/weather-news/first-tornado-twister-2025-video)

**California wildfire alert camera captures video of country's first tornado of 2025**
A tornado was spotted in Northern California on Friday, marking the country's first tornado of 2025. The tornado was detected by a camera designed to monitor wildfires and smoke, rather than severe weather. According to the National Weather Service, the tornado lasted for 3 minutes and had an estimated path of about 0.8 miles. However, due to its remote location and lack of damage, the tornado was not rated on the Enhanced Fujita Wind Scale. California typically experiences fewer than a dozen tornadoes each year, and they are generally on the weaker end of the scale. The state has seen fewer than 500 reported tornadoes since 1950, resulting in injuries but no fatalities. The total number of tornadoes in the US in 2024 is over 40% higher than the average year, with at least 1,735 tornadoes reported.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 04, 2025 04:35 AM
Source:[Yahoo](https://www.yahoo.com/news/california-wildfire-alert-camera-captures-043555811.html)

**2024: Second-most tornadoes on record, marks highest EF-2+ count since 2011**
According to the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center, 2024 has seen the second-highest number of tornadoes on record, with at least 1,735 confirmed tornadoes. This is just behind 2004, which holds the top spot with 1,817 tornadoes. Notably, 2024 has recorded the highest number of EF-2+ and EF-3+ tornadoes since 2011, indicating the intensity of this year's storms. In the Houston area, the NWS has confirmed at least 11 tornadoes in just three days in December 2024. The increase in tornadoes is attributed to advances in technology and easier access to reporting, which has led to more accurate documentation of weaker tornadoes. 'This is the 2nd most tornadoes on record behind 2004 (1817),' the NWS reports. 
Original language: en
Publish date: January 04, 2025 01:27 AM
Source:[click2houston.com](https://www.click2houston.com/news/local/2025/01/04/2024-second-most-tornadoes-on-record-marks-highest-ef-2-count-since-2011/)

**Year in review: Ice storm, microburst, & tornadoes**
The Tennessee Valley experienced an active year for weather, with a January ice storm, a microburst, and a tornado outbreak in May. The National Weather Service (NWS) Office in Huntsville reported 27 tornadoes within their forecast area, with 20 in Alabama and 7 in Tennessee. The majority of these tornadoes occurred during the May 8-9 tornado outbreak, which included two EF3, one EF2, 13 EF1, and four EF0 tornadoes. The final tornado of 2024 was an EF1 with maximum winds of 100 mph, causing significant damage in downtown Athens. Pooja Simpson, the weekend evening meteorologist, said, 'Having lived in Huntsville and experiencing the tragedy firsthand, she realized she wanted to do something that could help those in her community.' The Weather Authority welcomed Simpson to the team earlier this year, and she has a passion for severe weather. 'The over 100-year-old tree that stood outside the courthouse came down in the storm,' said Simpson. The Weather Authority will continue to keep you updated when severe weather threatens the area in 2025.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 01, 2025 04:08 AM
Source:[whnt.com](https://whnt.com/weather/valleywx-blog/year-in-review-ice-storm-microburst-tornadoes/)

**Like a bad guest, Ohio's 2024 tornado season came early, stayed late, and was terrible**
Ohio's 2024 tornado season was the worst in the state's history, breaking a 32-year-old record with 74 tornadoes. The season began on February 28 and ended on December 29, with the worst tornado striking the Indian Lake region on March 14, killing three people and injuring dozens. The state's top 10 counties for tornadoes all saw three or more this year. Meteorologist Brandon Peloquin warned that while it's not clear how active the severe weather season in 2025 will be, it's essential that everyone be prepared. Tornado season in Ohio typically peaks between April and June, but March is also a primary month for tornadoes. Tornadoes are confirmed by surveying damage in person, looking for patterns such as larger uprooted trees crossing each other. 'It's been relentless,' Peloquin said about the Ohio tornado season. 'The jet stream lined up just right to direct multiple strong systems through the Ohio Valley.' 
Original language: en
Publish date: December 31, 2024 03:41 PM
Source:[Yahoo](https://www.yahoo.com/news/bad-guest-ohios-2024-tornado-124134076.html)

**2024 Could End With Second Most US Tornadoes**
According to the Storm Prediction Center (SPC), 2024 could end as the second most active year for tornadoes in the US, with a preliminary estimated count of 1,641 tornadoes as of December 30. The National Weather Service is still conducting storm surveys, and the number is expected to rise. Notable tornado outbreaks this year include the Spring tornadoes, which were the most active April-May period in 74 years, with 883 tornadoes, and the Chicago derecho, which spawned over 46 tornadoes, including 32 in the Chicago area alone. The year also saw a record number of tornadoes in Arkansas and Indiana, and a strong EF3 tornado in Mt. Vernon, Indiana. The final tally for 2024 tornadoes will be confirmed once the NWS finishes all of their storm surveys. Jennifer Gray, a weather and climate writer for weather.com, notes that 2024 has been a historic year for tornadoes, and the final count will be able to confirm how it stacks up in the record books. 'We won't see a full tally from the most recent tornado outbreak until the NWS finishes all of their storm surveys, however, we know that it spawned over two dozen tornadoes, which will only add to the final count for 2024 tornadoes,' Gray said. 'While December tornadoes aren't typically that numerous, winter outbreaks can occur, at times, in the South.'
Original language: en
Publish date: December 31, 2024 11:10 AM
Source:[The Weather Channel](https://weather.com/storms/tornado/news/2024-12-30-second-most-tornadoes-on-record-2024)

**5 Weather Wishes We Have For 2025**
The Weather Channel has outlined five weather-related wishes for 2025, hoping for a less destructive year. The wishes include fewer landfalling hurricanes, quieter severe weather, widespread drought relief, and fewer deadly flood events. In 2024, there were 18 named storms, 11 hurricanes, and 5 major hurricanes, with eight of them making landfall. The year also saw 1,473 confirmed tornadoes, 17 severe weather events, and 166 flood-related deaths. The channel hopes for a quieter severe weather year, with fewer tornadoes and less destruction. They also wish for drought relief, with over a third of the country under drought conditions as of December 24. Additionally, they hope for fewer deadly flood events, with 166 deaths attributed to floods in 2024, significantly higher than the 30-year average of 89 fatalities per year. 'We are hoping a wetter pattern across the South will emerge in the spring of 2025 that will bring more precipitation and hopefully help to diminish drought in those areas,' said the channel. 'We wish next year is much quieter in terms of severe weather and that fewer tornadoes wreak havoc across the country,' they added.
Original language: en
Publish date: December 30, 2024 02:09 PM
Source:[The Weather Channel](https://weather.com/forecast/national/news/2024-12-19-weather-wishes-2025-relief-disasters)

**Tornado Outbreak 'Likely' In The South Through Saturday Night, NOAA's Storm Prediction Center Says**
A tornado outbreak is 'likely' in parts of the South through Saturday night, according to NOAA's Storm Prediction Center. Strong tornadoes, damaging straight-line winds, large hail, and heavy rainfall are concerns, especially on Saturday and Saturday night. The area at risk includes parts of Louisiana, Mississippi, and western Alabama, where a level 4 out of 5 severe weather risk has been issued. The Storm Prediction Center warns that this corridor could see strong, long-track tornadoes (EF3 or higher intensity) if the right atmospheric ingredients come together. The main time of concern is Saturday afternoon into Saturday night, with two rounds of severe thunderstorms possible. Locally flooding rainfall is also a threat through Saturday night from eastern Texas to the Tennessee Valley. Severe storms will continue to march eastward on Sunday into much of the Southeast and extending northward into portions of the upper Ohio Valley and Appalachians.
Original language: en
Publish date: December 28, 2024 11:45 AM
Source:[Aol](https://www.aol.com/severe-weather-packs-tornado-threat-125435937.html)

**2024 had some wild weather. Here's why.**
The 2024 hurricane and tornado seasons were 'hyperactive', with 18 named storms and 1,762 preliminary tornado reports. La Niña conditions, which include cooler than average water temperatures in the eastern Pacific, are to blame. La Niña brings sinking air in the Pacific, which is counteracted by rising air in the Atlantic, making it easier for hurricanes to form. The relationship between La Niña and tornadoes is more nuanced, but research suggests that the Great Plains see an uptick in tornadoes during La Niña years due to the shifting position of the jet stream. This year, La Niña conditions emerged in the autumn, but quick swings between El Niño and La Niña can result in booming or busting tornado barrages. The U.S. Great Plains saw repeated onslaughts of destructive tornadoes, and the conditions for next year's weather are uncertain. According to emerging research, if La Niña conditions weaken in the spring and shift back toward El Niño, it could lead to near average or slightly below average hurricane activity, but the Deep South may see extra activity in February or March, and Kansas and Oklahoma may see increased tornado activity in April.
Original language: en
Publish date: December 28, 2024 11:00 AM
Source:[Washington Post](https://www.washingtonpost.com/weather/2024/12/26/la-nina-hurricane-tornado-season/)

**The biggest weather stories of the year for Indiana 2024**
Indiana experienced a year of active weather in 2024, with 57 tornadoes, 91 severe hail reports, and 378 severe wind damage reports. The top 10 weather stories of the year include a cloudiest month in January, a snow burst in February, multiple tornadoes in March, a total solar eclipse in April, a G5 geomagnetic storm in May, a flash drought in June, severe storms and tornadoes in July, high winds from Hurricane Helene in September, and early snow in November. The year ended with a record-breaking start to the snow season.
Original language: en
Publish date: December 27, 2024 02:14 PM
Source:[wthr.com](https://www.wthr.com/article/weather/weather-blog/weather-top-10-stories-forecast-space-sky-tornado-snow-snowfall-how-much-rain-wind-hurricane-2024/531-d858287d-9c5b-49aa-af67-43694a18ee5a)

**Reviewing the severe weather and tornadoes during 2024**
The United States has experienced a significant increase in tornadoes in 2024, with 1,321 confirmed tornadoes, nearly 100 above the average of 1,225. This has led to an increase in fatalities, with 83 reported for the year. The St. Louis region has seen more than 40 confirmed tornadoes, with a weak tornado reported near the Lake of the Ozarks and several tornado warnings in the area. The increase in tornadoes is attributed to La Nina Winters, which have been linked to severe weather events in the past. As the country shifts into the holiday season, it is essential to remain severe weather aware to avoid overlooking potential severe weather events.
Original language: en
Publish date: December 18, 2024 01:43 PM
Source:[fox2now.com](https://fox2now.com/news/weather/reviewing-the-severe-weather-and-tornadoes-during-2024/)

forecasters.initial_reasoning: In forecasting the number of tornadoes reported by NOAA for March 2025, I consider the climatological base rates from historical tornado data in the United States. March marks the beginning of the tornado season, especially in the Southern Plains, the Gulf Coast, and parts of the Midwest. Analyzing historical March data, in recent decades, the number of reports generally falls within the range of 30 to 100. However, extreme instances can result in counts below 30 or above 100. Based on historical trends, the base rates I propose are: '0 to 29': 20%, '30 to 54': 30%, '55 to 79': 30%, '80 and above': 20%. These distributions reflect lower probabilities for the extremes ('0 to 29' and '80 and above'), with a more even likelihood for moderate activity ('30 to 54' and '55 to 79') based on past patterns.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Weather Patterns and Predictions
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Considering the current weather predictions for March 2025, if there are signals of strong La Nina conditions, this would generally correlate with increased tornado activity, particularly in the Southern U.S. Neutral or El Nino conditions might lead to decreased activity. Given no specific predictions from NWP models indicating a strong La Nina effect, the probabilities remain unchanged.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Climate Change Impact Trends
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Recent research suggests climate change may impact tornado frequency and intensity, but there is still significant uncertainty in predictability. Some studies propose an increase in outbreaks, while others observe shifts in tornado alley's geographic extent. The current understanding does not lead to a confident adjustment, thus maintaining the initial probabilities.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Soil Moisture and Precipitation Levels
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: High soil moisture levels and increased precipitation can influence severe weather conditions, potentially leading to more tornadoes. Current climatological data does not indicate significantly above-normal precipitation or soil moisture for March 2025, so there's no adjustment needed.

forecasters.initial_reasoning: To forecast the number of tornadoes for March 2025, I will initially base my probability distribution on historical frequencies of tornado counts reported by NOAA for the month of March over past years. Historically, March is the beginning of the tornado season in the United States, with variability depending on weather patterns like El Niño or La Niña. Based on historical data from NOAA, we can estimate the distribution of tornado counts. For this exercise, I'll assume these generic probabilities: a relatively low likelihood for the '80 and above' due to the rarity of extremely high tornado counts in March, increasing probabilities in the middle due to moderate tornado activity typically observed in March. Uunusually low tornado numbers (0 to 29) are less common due to this period marking the start of the tornado season.

perspective_derived_factors.name: El Niño/La Niña Cycles
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: El Niño and La Niña significantly affect weather patterns. An El Niño tends to suppress tornado activity in the early part of the tornado season, including March, whereas La Niña can enhance tornado occurrences due to changes in atmospheric circulation patterns that favor tornado formation.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Long-Range Temperature Forecasts
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Warmer than average temperatures across the central U.S. during March can lead to increased instability and therefore a higher chance of tornado occurrences.

forecasters.initial_reasoning: To establish an initial probability distribution for the number of tornadoes reported by NOAA in March 2025, I will refer to historical data on March tornado occurrences in the United States from prior years. Between 1991 and 2020, NOAA reported an average of about 77 tornadoes in March, with some variation due to annual weather patterns. The distribution of tornado occurrences typically shows that a large portion falls within the range of 30 to 79 tornadoes. Therefore, I will allocate higher probabilities to the '30 to 54' and '55 to 79' ranges, with a smaller but significant probability to the '80 and above' range. The '0 to 29' range will have the lowest probability, as it is rare for March to have so few tornadoes reported.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Weather Pattern Anomalies
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Significant weather pattern anomalies, such as La Niña or El Niño, can affect the atmospheric conditions that lead to tornado formation. For instance, La Niña tends to bring cooler and wetter conditions in the southern U.S., which can enhance tornado activity. Monitoring these anomalies helps adjust expectations.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Advancements in Early Warning Systems
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Improvements in early warning systems and storm tracking can lead to better detection and reporting of tornadoes, potentially recognizing transient tornadoes that might have been missed in past decades.

forecasters.initial_reasoning: To estimate the number of tornadoes NOAA might report for March 2025, I begin by examining historical data from past years. On average, March in the U.S. sees between 80 to 110 tornadoes, according to NOAA's Storm Prediction Center's historical tornado data. These numbers serve as a base rate for this forecast. However, the counts can vary significantly year to year due to variations in atmospheric conditions. For the initial distribution, I will assume a slightly conservative estimate by focusing on historical deviations seen in the data.
